origin: Middle English (in balance (sense 3 of the noun)): from Old French balance (noun), balancer (verb), based on late Latin (libra) bilanx ‘(balance) having two scale pans’, from bi- ‘twice, having two’ + lanx ‘scale pan’.

definitions.definition: An even distribution of weight enabling someone or something to remain upright and steady.
definitions.example: she lost her balance before falling

definitions.definition: A condition in which different elements are equal or in the correct proportions.
definitions.example: try to keep a balance between work and relaxation

definitions.definition: An apparatus for weighing, especially one with a central pivot, beam, and a pair of scales.
definitions.example: The atomic weight of an element - the quantity chemists could weigh with scales and balances - depends on the number of protons and neutrons, which have virtually equal masses.
Allow centrifugal force to provide balance while both skates tip onto their left edges in the turn.

definitions.definition: A predominating weight or amount; the majority.
definitions.example: the balance of opinion was that work was more important than leisure

definitions.definition: A figure representing the difference between credits and debits in an account; the amount of money held in an account.
definitions.example: he accumulated a healthy balance with the savings bank

definitions.definition: Keep or put (something) in a steady position so that it does not fall.
definitions.example: a mug that she balanced on her knee

definitions.definition: Offset or compare the value of (one thing) with another.
definitions.example: the cost of obtaining such information needs to be balanced against its benefits

definitions.definition: Compare debits and credits in (an account), typically to ensure that they are equal.
definitions.example: the law requires the council to balance its books each year
